awd_titl_txt: SBIR Phase I:  Optimizing Safety and Fuel Efficiency in Autonomous Rendezvous and Proximity Operations (RPO) of Uncooperative Objects
awd_abstract_narration:
This Small Business Innovation Research (SBIR) Phase I project will enable a novel class of in-space proximity operations. This research has the potential not only to sustain and improve space operations, but also to strengthen national security and result in a thriving economy in space.  The expected advances include sophisticated capabilities for satellite inspection, repair/upgrade, end-of-life servicing, debris remediation, and even manufacturing and assembly operations. This project's emphasis on the safety, robustness, and autonomy of missions also ultimately paves the way for safer human spaceflight operations and contributes to vital areas like debris mitigation and collision avoidance. This effort also extends to the exploration of frontier technologies such as asteroid mining.  This project's approach creates commercial opportunities and unlocks the in-orbit servicing, assembly, and manufacturing value chain.

This SBIR Phase I project will synthesize Neural Lyapunov functions, which can be integrated into filter schemes for any type of control system that accepts state feedback from multi-sensor measurements. The primary objective of this study is to enable the inspection and capture of uncooperative, uncontrolled, and unprepared objects. This ability is achieved by fusing data from multiple sensors and applying barrier functions, rooted in Neural Lyapunov theory, to ensure safety within actuation limits and state constraints during the docking and 'combined stack' phases (i.e., when a servicer is docked with a client spacecraft). Furthermore, this technology developed path planning algorithms that use real-time optical measurements to account for the detumbling rates of client satellites, ensuring safer inspection and docking maneuvers. These steps are critical for ensuring safe autonomous operations during the docking phase and combined stack maneuvers. The final outcome of this research is to develop a mission design, analysis, and planning tool to help operators account for different mission scenarios involving in-orbit proximity operations, while analyzing tradeoffs of safety assurance versus fuel optimization.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.
org_dir_long_name: Directorate for Technology, Innovation, and Partnerships

por.por_cntn:
Project Overview:

Our project aimed to enhance the safety and fuel efficiency of autonomous spacecraft during Rendezvous and Proximity Operations (RPO) with uncooperative objects, such as defunct satellites, hostile objects, or space debris. Traditional spacecraft controllers often struggle with the complex dynamics and uncertainties inherent in space environments. To address these challenges, we developed an advanced control algorithm known as Neural Control Lyapunov Barrier Functions (Neural CLBF) and compared its performance with established controllers like the Linear Quadratic Regulator (LQR) and Model Predictive Control (MPC).

Intellectual Merit:

We successfully expanded the Neural CLBF framework to three-dimensional space, allowing control over both the position and orientation of spacecraft—known as six degrees of freedom (6-DOF). Using high-fidelity simulation environments like MuJoCo and NASA's Astrobee simulator, we demonstrated that Neural CLBF can effectively handle nonlinear spacecraft dynamics and complex operational constraints, including collision avoidance and line-of-sight limitations.

Key achievements include:

  • Improved Success Rates: Achieved a 77% success rate in mission simulations without violating safety constraints.
  • Enhanced Fuel Efficiency: Demonstrated a 56.37% average efficiency in fuel consumption compared to traditional controllers.
  • Robustness and Safety: Fine-tuned the Neural CLBF hyperparameters to improve performance under uncertainties like model inaccuracies and external disturbances.

Broader Impacts:

The advancements from this project have significant implications beyond spacecraft control:

  • Space Industry Applications: Improved autonomous RPO can benefit satellite servicing, debris removal, and inspection missions, making space operations safer and more sustainable.
  • Autonomous Drone Applications: By slightly adapting our Neural CLBF controller for fully autonomous commercial and military drones, we enhance their safety, efficiency, and operational capabilities for combat, delivery and logistics, law enforcement and border patrol, industrial inspection and maintenance, agriculture, firefighting, and search and rescue. This cross-industry application allows for rapid testing and maturation of the technology, accelerating its deployment in the market and attracting private investment.
  • Defense and National Security: Enhanced capabilities for autonomous tracking and reactive control maneuvers contribute to national security by protecting valuable space assets and augmenting air combat capabilities.
  • Technological Innovation: Our work contributes to the fields of robotics and artificial intelligence by providing frameworks for handling complex tasks in uncertain environments, which can be applied to sensors, drones, humanoid robots, and autonomous vehicles.
  • Workforce Development: We hired and trained engineers and interns, enriching the talent pool with expertise in AI/ML, advanced control systems, aerospace engineering, space operations, and Space Domain Awareness (SDA).
  • Cross-Sector Collaboration: By sharing our findings through public GitHub repositories, collaborations with industry, government, and academia, and presentations at industry events, we fostered transparency and encouraged strong collaboration within the aerospace community.

Conclusions:

This project demonstrated the feasibility and advantages of using advanced neural control algorithms for autonomous spacecraft operations involving uncooperative objects. The Neural CLBF controller showed superior performance in safety, robustness, and in some instances fuel efficiency compared to traditional methods. Our findings provide valuable insights and tools that can be leveraged by the aerospace industry to enhance the safety and effectiveness of current and future space missions.

Recognizing the broader applications of our technology, we target the fully autonomous commercial and military drones market. By applying our advanced control algorithms to drones, we can test and mature the technology more rapidly and easily, accelerate go-to-market timelines, stimulate growth, and attract private investment.

By addressing critical challenges in autonomous spacecraft control, our project supports the advancement of space technology and contributes to safer, more efficient air and space operations. The impact of this work extends to various sectors, including defense, commercial and military space, commercial and military drones, and broader technological innovation, ultimately benefiting society through improved services and increased safety in all domain operations.


Last Modified: 11/18/2024
Modified by: Axel Garcia

Images (1 of )
  • Diagram shows RL with neural Lyapunov and barrier controllers for RPO maneuvers. Inputs form state x(t) for the RL controller. RL outputs actions u via policy π to minimize fuel, ensure stability, manage distance. Actions u are validated by Lyapunov and barrier functions.
    Orbital Services Corporation LLC (OSCorp)
    Copyrighted
    Axel Garcia
    Software Architecture Block Diagram
  • Plot shows Neural CLBF demonstrating superior performance with fewer obstacles through training in MuJoCo physics engine simulated environment. LQR demonstrated an upward trend with increased number of obstacles.
    Orbital Services Corporation LLC (OSCorp)
    Copyrighted
    Axel Garcia
    Comparison of Controller Success Rates Vs. Number of Obstacles
  • Final results show agents achieving 77% success rate overall and 56.37% average efficiency in training simulations.
    Orbital Services Corporation LLC (OSCorp)
    Copyrighted
    Axel Garcia
    Increased Complexity Training Results
  • Out of 62 total runs with 248 agents, 179 agents successfully reached their goals, resulting in a success rate of 72.2%. There were 69 collisions, leading to a collision rate of 27.8%. This chart displays the performance metrics of the agents during the simulations.
    Orbital Services Corporation LLC (OSCorp)
    Copyrighted
    Axel Garcia
    Large Scale Training Results
